journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Non-linear proportional–integral–derivative synthesis for unstable non-linear systems using describing function inversion with experimental verification

contrib-group.aff: Faculty of Engineering, The University of Nottingham – Malaysia Campus, Selangor, Malaysia.

author-notes.corresp: *Materials, Mechanics, and Structures Research Division, Faculty of Engineering, The University of Nottingham – Malaysia Campus, Semenyih, Selangor, Malaysia. email: amir.nassir@nottingham.edu.my

abstract.p: This paper demonstrates a new non-linear proportional–integral–derivative (PID) controller synthesis approach using a describing function inversion technique for unstable systems where a mathematical model may not be available. The approach is applied to an inverted pendulum experimental set-up whose dynamic behaviour is very sensitive to the amplitude level of excitation. The procedure involves stabilization of the unstable system followed by generation of the describing function models of the stabilized closed-loop system. Then, the corresponding unstable open-loop frequency domain models at various operating regimes are extracted. A controller at nominal conditions is designed, followed by obtaining the corresponding desired open-loop frequency domain model. A set of controllers that force the open-loop behaviour of the system mimic, which is desired at various operating regimes, is designed by optimization. Finally, the controller gains are inverted using a describing function inversion technique followed by experimental verification. The non-linear PID design is compared with two other alternative designs. The experimental results indicate that the proposed approach is a viable and effective non-linear controller synthesis technique for use with unstable non-linear systems.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Synthesizing controllers using describing function techniques may have been detected over fifty years ago [1, 2]. Systematic describing function techniques are formally introduced in reference [3], and they are developed in references [4] to [7]. Competitive work is reported in references [8] and [9]. A mixture of robust techniques and describing function techniques is developed in reference [10]. The proposed work in reference [3] has not been experimentally verified, and all related literature has been limited to stable plants. The primary contributions of this work are twofold: (1) extension of the non-linear proportional–integral–derivative (PID) synthesis technique presented in references [4] to [11] to the unstable plant case and (2) experimental verification of the proposed synthesis approach.

sec.title: 2 Review of Theory Development
sec.p: In this section, the primary mathematical development of the theory behind the developed synthesis procedure is presented; a brief description of the synthesis procedure is also given. The structure of the considered non-linear feedback system is shown in Fig. 1. The class of non-linear plants considered is given by the following expressions

caption.p: The schematic diagram of the considered non-linear feedback system

sec.p: There are no restrictions on the type of non-linear functions f and g (i.e. they could be continuous, discontinuous, single- or multivalued), the number of non-linear terms, non-linearity arrangement (i.e. non-linearities could be in the forward path or feedback path), or plant order.

sec.title: 2.1 Input–output characterization
sec.p: In order to characterize the input–output behaviour of plants represented by equations (1) and (2), a describing function approach is utilized. The primary advantages of such an approach are outlined below.

list-item.p: A controller synthesis method based on sinusoidal-input describing function (SIDF) models would be applicable to amplitude sensitive non-linear plants. It is noted that this amplitude sensitivity issue is the most important characteristic of a non-linear plant that distinguishes the non-linear plant from its linear counterpart.
A design based on one or more SIDF models, which covers the expected range of excitation amplitudes, provides a fundamental basis for a robust design.
Small-signal models, in contrast to the non-linear plant, are only a function of frequency, and do not include the effects of amplitude levels of excitations.

When deriving small-signal models, each non-linear term is characterized by one parameter, which is the gain or the slope of the non-linearity at a specific operating point; however, an SIDF model (for the whole plant) is characterized by one parameter, which is the amplitude of the excitation. Generally speaking, linear robust design methods based on small-signal models result in feedback systems that are conservative in the sense that they reduce performance in order to achieve absolute stability.

sec.p:
There are several approaches that may be used to obtain an SIDF model of a non-linear plant; the easiest approach is to use sinusoids with known amplitudes and frequencies (i.e.
u

sec.title: 2.2 SIDF inversion
sec.p: The other mathematical development that it is necessary to be familiar with in order to complete the synthesis of SIDF-based non-linear controllers corresponds to that of the SIDF inversion. During the course of the synthesis procedure, the SIDF models of the controller gains are obtained; the goal is to determine the as yet unknown non-linear gain functions whose describing function models are known. This is a fairly simple task, and it is done by minimizing the following objective function

For an assumed non-linear function (e.g. see Fig. 2) with an initial guess for the independent variables describing the assumed non-linear function (e.g.
m , d , δ

m , d , δ
) are varied by the optimization routine (e.g. fminsearch function of MATLAB®) until a satisfactory solution is obtained.

caption.p: Frequency domain models of the unstable plant (a corresponds to the amplitude of the sinusoid at the input to the plant)

sec.title: 2.3 Brief outline of the synthesis procedure
sec.p: A summary of the synthesis procedure follows.

list-item.p: Stabilize the unstable non-linear plant.
Generate the SIDF models of the stabilized plant.
With the known stabilizing controller and the SIDF models of step 2, extract the SIDF models of the unstable plant. Then, choose one of these models and design a linear PID controller.

Generate the SIDF model of the closed-loop system in step 3. With the known controller of step 3 and results of the SIDF generation of this step, extract the desired open-loop behaviour, denoted
C *
G *
.

Use optimization and generate a set of PID gains that would force the open-loop non-linear system operating at different operating regimes to mimic
C *
G *
.
Invert the non-linearities obtained in step 5.
Verify design.

sec.title: 3 Main Developments
sec.p: The problem statement is to develop an approach for synthesis of non-linear PID controllers for highly non-linear unstable systems with no restrictions on the number of non-linear terms, non-linearity type (could be continuous and/or discontinuous), arrangement (could be in the forward path and/or in the feedback path), and system order; the approach is to be demonstrated by applying the procedure to a highly non-linear inverted pendulum experimental set-up. The term ‘highly non-linear’ arises from the fact that the dynamic behaviour of the non-linear plant is very sensitive to the amplitude level of excitation. See Appendix 2 for a description of the experimental set-up.
The developed synthesis procedure is composed of seven primary steps as follows.

list-item.p: Stabilize the unstable non-linear system around the operating regimes of interest. For problems where a mathematical model is available, a variety of techniques such as sliding mode techniques could be used [12]. For cases where a mathematical model is not available, intuition may be used. For example, for the experimental set-up considered here, it is found that a linear proportional controller with a gain of 10 may be used to stabilize the system; this is accomplished by experiments and no mathematical model is used in this case. The primary reason for execution of this step is that evaluation of Fourier integrals (see equation (3)) would be meaningless if the output is not bounded; therefore, for unstable plants it would not be possible to obtain the SIDF models unless the plant is stabilized first.

Generate the sinusoidal-input describing function models of the stabilized closed-loop system around the operating regimes of interest. In this case, sinusoids with known amplitudes and frequencies (i.e.
u
( t )
= a cos
(
ω t
)
, where
u
is the input,
a
is the amplitude of excitation,
ω
is the frequency, and
t
is the time variable) are used to excite the stabilized closed-loop non-linear system, and outputs are recorded. Then, the corresponding SIDF models are obtained as outlined in the previous section. In this work, since a mathematical model is not available, experiments are conducted to obtain the output time histories followed by evaluation of Fourier integrals. If a mathematical model exists, then the model may be used to generate the corresponding output time histories. The user may choose to fit a linear model to each of the identified closed-loop frequency domain models. For example, for the example problem under study at nominal conditions (i.e. a reference amplitude of 20 degrees) the following closed-loop transfer function may be identified by using the invfreqs function of MATLAB®

With the known stabilizing controller of step 1, and the closed-loop frequency domain model of the previous step, use algebra and determine the corresponding unstable open-loop frequency domain models denoted
G
(
j ω ;
a i
)
. For the inverted pendulum problem, the corresponding unstable open-loop frequency domain model at the nominal condition is determined to be as follows.

The set of unstable open-loop models are determined using algebra and are depicted in Fig. 2. The spread in the pseudo-Bode plots indicates that the system is highly non-linear. If this were a linear plant, then there would be only one pseudo-Bode plot for all excitation amplitudes. In short, the objective of this step is to obtain the frequency domain behaviour of the unstable non-linear plant, which is required for design of a controller.

Select one of the models of the previous step as the nominal model and design a PID controller. Use the MATLAB® function developed in references [13] and [14] and design a linear PID controller, denoted by
C *
. In this case, the model corresponding to equation (7) is selected, the MATLAB® function cad_controller developed in references [13] and [14] is used, and the following PD (integral gain turns out to be negligible, i.e.
K I
≈ 0
) controller is designed

The primary inputs to the cad_controller function are the plant given by equation (7) and a desired closed-loop transfer function; in this case, a second-order transfer function with a damping ratio of 0.9 and a settling time of 0.5 second is specified to be the desired closed-loop transfer function. The output of the above-mentioned function is the proportional, derivative (PD) controller given by equation (8). As described previously, in this research, the nominal controller is not designed experimentally; however, experiments could be used to carry out the objective of this step. Therefore, the objective of this step is to obtain one controller at a specific operating regime of interest that would be used to arrive at the desired open-loop frequency domain behaviour.

Generate the closed-loop sinusoidal-input describing function model of the system comprised of the controller of the previous step and the non-linear plant similar to what is done in step 2. In this research, since a mathematical model is not available, experiments are conducted to obtain the output time histories for a sinusoidal excitation. Then, with the known desired closed-loop SIDF model and the known controller of step 3, use algebra and determine the desired open-loop frequency domain model, denoted by
C *
G *
; in this case, the open-loop system is comprised of the controller in series with the non-linear plant with no feedback. For the inverted pendulum problem, this is shown in Fig. 3. In other words, the objective of this step is to determine the desired open-loop behaviour that could be used to design a set of controllers that would force the non-linear system to have the same identical and desired open-loop frequency domain behaviour at various operating regimes.

caption.p: The desired open-loop frequency domain model (e is the amplitude of the sinusoid at the input to the controller)

list-item.p: Design a set of linear PID controllers at various operating regimes of interest that mimic the desired open-loop behaviour obtained in the previous step. This is accomplished by minimizing the following objective function

data of step 1 coupled with interpolation. This will allow this step to be executed using standard available personal computers. The output of this step is a set of values for the parameters of the PID compensator at various operating regimes of interest. For the inverted pendulum problem, the optimized values of the PD controller (the gain for integral action is determined to be negligible) are given in Table 1. These amplitude-dependent parameters are treated as describing function models of the desired non-linear gains of the non-linear controller.

caption.p: The amplitude-dependent gains of the PD controller

list-item.p:
The corresponding open-loop frequency domain behaviour of the open-loop system comprised of the controllers given in Table 1 and the unstable plants derived in step 2 are depicted in Fig. 4. Therefore, the objective of this step is to arrive at the SIDF models of the controller gains. This objective may not be executed experimentally, and, as already described, a numerical approach is used to accomplish the objective of this step. It may be argued that the open-loop models derived in step 2 could be used together with the cad_controller software to arrive at a set of PID controllers without having to execute step 4. Generally speaking, such a procedure is usually not very systematic and straightforward; it might not be possible to design a linear PID by obtaining a fitted linear model and by application of classical control theory. For example, for the inverted pendulum under study, the authors could not design a linear PID at small amplitude levels of excitation (where the effects of friction are pronounced) using fitted transfer functions. However, it is possible to find a
C *
at regimes where non-linearities are not so pronounced and proceed to determine
C *
G *
; these
C *
G *
data coupled with the unstable plant data of step 2 (see Fig. 2) and optimization is then used to arrive at the desired gains. In this case, no fitting is done to optimize the gains.

caption.p: The frequency domain models of the open-loop system comprise the amplitude-dependent controllers and the unstable non-linear plant

list-item.p: Determine a set of non-linear functions whose SIDF models mimic the SIDF models of the compensator parameters that were determined in the previous step. A typical non-linear function that the user may select is shown in Fig. 5. The parameters of this function are determined in such a manner that the SIDF model approximates the amplitude-dependent gains of the compensator parameters at various operating regimes of interest. Such a function will allow for high gains at low amplitudes, constant gains at specific amplitude ranges, and gain reductions or jumps at specific amplitudes. Note that this step is the inverse of activities of step 2. In step 2, the model is available and the SIDF models are to be obtained; in this step, the SIDF models are known and the non-linearity model must be obtained. In order to determine the parameters of the non-linearity function shown in Fig. 4, optimization is used, and the fminsearch function of the MATLAB® software is utilized. The details of this inversion process are [15]: (a) use the describing function generator MATLAB® function [16] and generate the describing function model of the non-linearity; (b) if satisfactory results are obtained, then stop; otherwise, use the fminsearch function of the MATLAB® in order to modify the independent variables and go to (a).

caption.p: The candidate non-linear function that is used in the describing function inversion process

list-item.p: With reference to Fig. 5, for the inverted pendulum example, the results of the SIDF inversion using the software outlined in reference [15] are given in Table 2. The quality of fit is shown in Figs 6 and 7. In short, the objective of this step is to arrive at the non-linear functions describing the gains of the controller as a function of the error signal; this step must be executed using a numerical procedure.

caption.p: The quality of fit after SIDF inversion for the proportional non-linear gain
The quality of fit after SIDF inversion for the derivative non-linear gain

list-item.p: Finally, the design is verified using experiments. The normalized step response plots of the closed-loop system at various operating regimes of interest are depicted in Fig. 8. This figure demonstrates the results of the design verification step. The normalized step responses at various amplitudes of reference signals indicate that closed-loop system behaviour is fairly insensitive to the amplitude level of the command signal. It is observed that at lower step magnitudes high-frequency oscillations exist. The main cause of this is because at the connection point of the pendulum to the shaft of the motor there is a two degree free play. The stability test is shown in Fig. 9. In this figure, the pseudo-frequency response plots of the closed-loop system comprised of the designed non-linear PD compensator and the non-linear process are successfully generated; hence, stability at operating regimes of interest is demonstrated.

caption.p: Normalized step-response plots of the synthesized non-linear closed-loop system
Stability test (r corresponds to the amplitude of the sinusoid for the reference signal)

list-item.p: A linear PD controller based on one frequency domain model is designed for comparison purposes; the corresponding normalized step response plots are shown in Fig. 10. Inclusion of an integral term could decrease the steady state error; however, it further degrades the overall response in terms of larger settling time, overshoot, and an increase in sensitivity of the closed-loop system to the amplitude level of excitation.

caption.p: The normalized step-response plots with the single-range linear controller

list-item.p: It is apparent that the single-range linear controller design is not satisfactory (because of sensitivity and large steady state errors) and the non-linear PD controller is preferred. Another linear controller based on two frequency domain models is also designed [17–19]; the corresponding normalized step response plots are shown in Fig. 11.

caption.p: The normalized step-response plots with the dual-range linear controller

list-item.p: These results are competitive with the non-linear PD controller results; these results are consistent with theoretical work previously done in references [17] to [19].

sec.title: 4 Summary and Conclusions
sec.p: A new procedure for synthesis of non-linear PID controllers for use with highly non-linear unstable SISO systems is presented. The procedure is systematic and is composed of eight primary steps. Each step is a functional unit that drives the other steps of the procedure. In short, the synthesis procedure involves stabilization of the non-linear plant followed by determination of the SIDF models of the stabilized closed-loop system. Algebra is used and the unstable frequency domain open-loop models are obtained, followed by a linear controller design at nominal conditions. The desired open-loop frequency domain model is determined and a set of linear controllers that force the open-loop frequency domain models at all operating regimes that mimic that of the desired model is determined by optimization. The amplitude-dependent gains are inverted to obtain the non-linear functions describing the non-linear gains of the controller. Finally, the design is verified by obtaining the normalized step-response plots as well as the corresponding closed-loop frequency domain models for the stability test.

An experimental set-up consisting of an a.c. servomotor and an inverted pendulum is used to demonstrate the procedure. Based on the results of the experimental work, the following conclusions are made: (1) the non-linear PID synthesis procedure is effective and viable to be applied to highly non-linear SISO systems and (2) a stable robust design may be obtained.

sec.title: Experimental set-up
sec.p: The experimental rig is shown in Figs 12 to Figs 14. This set-up is comprised of an a.c. motor with a rated output of 2 kW, rated torque of 19.1 N m, maximum instantaneous torque of 57.3 N m, rated speed of 1000 r/min, maximum speed of 2000 r/min, rotor inertia of 98.4 × 10−4 kg m2, rated power rate of 37.0 kW/s, and a total weight of 27.4 kg. The encoder has a shaft diameter of 8 mm with a resolution of 2500 pulses/revolution and requires a power supply of 5 V d.c. The gear ratio is 5:1. An additional pulley with a mass configuration is added to increase the degree of instability of the plant by constantly pulling down on the pendulum from its equilibrium position, as shown in Fig. 15.

caption.p: The overall picture of the experimental rig
Pulley system to increase the degree of instability

sec.p: The pendulum is a solid steel bar with a 20 mm diameter and a length of 250 mm. The electronic instrumentation corresponds to National Instruments products with LabView software. There are also mechanisms for adjustable Coulomb friction and adjustable backlash that are not utilized in this research.

fn.p: This work was supported by the Malaysian Ministry of Science Technology and Innovation (MOSTI).
